title: Haverhill mayor names outside investigator to examine police leadership
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Local News The investigation will be limited in scope, and not include a review of a July incident where a man died while being detained by police.
A cruiser from the Haverhill Police Department.
Haverhill Police Department An outside investigation into the Haverhill Police Department is set to begin this week, with an attorney appointed by Mayor Melinda Barrett overseeing the review.

title: Uniqlo to open in long-vacant Downtown Crossing building
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Business The retailer will move into a high-profile property that has sat empty since 2006, as new owners look to bring more life back into the recovering shopping district.
The exterior of 399 Washington St.
in Downton Crossing.

title: North Andover officer shot by colleague must remain in jail, highest court rules
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Local News Kelsey Fitzsimmons was ordered to return to jail last month after saying that she could not safely use an alcohol testing device.
North Andover Police Officer Kelsey Fitzsimmons during her arraignment in August 2025.

Ben Pennington/The Boston Globe The North Andover police officer who was shot by a colleague in an “armed confrontation” earlier this year is set to remain in jail ahead of her trial after the state’s highest court ruled against her this week.

title: Xavier Tillman put his preseason game-winner into perspective
author: Aidan Buchanan
bullets: Boston Celtics “I got three kids, there's really nothing to stress about.
I got real life at home, so I'm not too worried about what happens here.
” Tillman celebrates after game-winner against the Raptors Wednesday night (Charles Krupa/AP).

title: 13 horror books experts say will actually scare you
author: Frances Klemm
bullets: Book Club Local authors, booksellers, and librarians share the terrifying reads they can’t forget.
Photo Courtesy Source Books ShareSend this article to your social connections.
With the countdown to Halloween ticking down, we asked Boston’s horror experts — from best-selling author Paul Tremblay to Boston Public Library staff — to share the books that truly terrified them.
